BFEEA4B5574046D3B95EC43CCA484288.description: Calculate the power dissipated by a resistor in a circuit.

DA523D5946284CA3970DC9AEED6AA84B.description: Apply Kirchoff’s rules in a circuit problem.

7028C822DC4B4B1B862F1E4CA94EE046.description: Analyze series and parallel circuits and demonstrate proficiency in calculations of equivalent resistance, current running through, and voltage drop across resistors.

18359698C2FB4369BC1666689FDA436A.description: Identify a short circuit in a circuit diagram.

94FD6768C4124BBB9BADCA3D777F06D5.description: Draw schematic diagrams of circuits described in problems.

520514A488CC47DE8467288982CBEEEA.description: Identify a circuit where the resistors are wired in series and a circuit where the resistors are wired in parallel.

0211E21549A249DC96CBF8958C2BD8E8.description: Wire a voltmeter and an ammeter in the proper way in a circuit.

4FE2EC2D2DA2486EBEF5B584141D0EE9.description: Find the resistance from a voltage vs. current graph and state whether the resistor is ohmic or non-ohmic from the shape of the curve.

31C7FBE40AC349D7B7166D1C362EFC48.description: *Apply the relationship between the electric field and the potential difference in a parallel plate configuration.

B4AB4D5E868046DAA1673C3FE2C70AE1.description: Apply the concepts of electric potential energy, electric potential, and electric potential difference in problems.

A41134B6034D41BAB51A6CAD9565FA50.description: *Calculate the electric field a given distance from several point charges, using appropriate vector addition methods.

2B8D80DA1D204EEABC948599859AC256.description: *Calculate the electric field a given distance from a point charge.

DCB2FFEDB7384017ABB3B326BCD0CDFB.description: Use Coulomb’s Law for two charges, and *to find the net force on a charge with two or more charges near it, using appropriate vector addition methods.

0DED9FCFF93B412A8E20077ED15B86C9.description: Use Coulomb’s Law to determine the electric force between two charged objects.

D8579462B5C14BF196D542BE47BD322F.description: *Draw the electric field with directions on field lines around a positive charge, a negative charge, between two like positive charges, between two negative charges, between a positive and negative charge.

502EDAFC70F14B73A972350AD8DCF46D.description: How to calculate power used by a circuit and power dissipated by a resistor.

26D43D708DA64248AC4CA3B1B48A439A.description: Apply Kirchoff’s two rules (the conservation of energy and the conservation of charge law with simple series and parallel circuits and *combination circuits.)

36B87EF3E83346F9A82DCC977A92896E.description: Define what a voltmeter measures and what an ammeter measures.

96BCE18666614DAE8488EC7305358F90.description: Interpret simple closed circuits and identifying what symbols are used for switches, resistance, conductors, batteries, voltmeters, ammeters.

443E48DBEF904C3A84A5B156DF04997C.description: Understand what Ohm’s Law is, and describe the relationship between the variables in it.

DCE3F871BB554EAB937341BAA6DD2762.description: Define resistance and the factors affecting the resistance of a conductor.

8BC7BDA288BB48CBBA99FA4FA65991B4.description: Know that conventional current flows the opposite direction of electrons.

98B7994416D744DF802D5193FD921110.description: State the definition of electric current as the rate of flow of charge.

39141E63B5E446A2ACA496876D9CDF2A.description: Define the concepts of electric potential energy, electric potential, and electric potential difference.

9E389B8572EC49B0A13530991F1DCA91.description: Know how to state Coulomb’s Law and describe the relationship between the distance and the charges of two objects with words. Realize that the force of charge A on charge B is the same as the force of charge B on charge A, but in opposite directions.

A04A4C5A66684CE8AC530760822B3987.description: Know charging by conduction (positive or negative)* and charging by induction (positive or negative).

7C909C422F234118A4F3A9F6BBCDB1DB.description: Know the difference between conductors and insulators and what on an atomic level causes this difference.

59DD935256E24ECD9EAED2032B7E6144.description: When an object loses electrons, some other object has to gain them. Charge is conserved in a system.

B14F414B855B46BB8FD1CCCDDE86DFA4.description: Understand that an object loses electrons to become positively charged. Know why it can’t gain protons to get positively charged. (protons are locked up in the nucleus; electrons in the outer energy levels can be easily removed in metals)

B61C0A831A3C433E9B6F38207BCD903E.description: *Understand the field lines are uniform between two parallel charged plates.

02E9D652972346F9BE794843B35564F7.description: *Understand the field lines are denser near the point charges and the field is stronger closer to the charge. The smaller the curvature of the charged object, the denser the field lines are.

3937692BDEB549ACBDB03D9807BBA522.description: *Know that the presence of an electric field exists around an object of charge and that this field exerts force on other charged objects in the field. Compare this to the gravitational field around a mass.

CCBF7DD1867E4CB1870B5ACF9AD42997.description: Know that like charges repel and unlike charges attract by an electrostatic force.

4D9A1487A4044B05B768872036F11BAE.description: Know that the fundamental charge is e, the charge of an electron. (See equation sheet). The charge of a proton is the same as the charge of an electron but positive instead of negative.

D78BEBD074AD4D81B500C95268868D67.description: *Know the relativistic effects on time, length, and mass as an object moves closer to the speed of light.

5B20E277DEA84679BE2A3A2280401482.description: *Relate nuclear energy and mass defect using E = mc

94798C38F85245439F95CC13D17C350A.description: *Determine the wavelength from a double slit diffraction pattern

4A85857678554292BAFB35A4040BA2D4.description: *Demonstrate proficiency in solving problems that use the lens equation to calculate the focal length of a lens, image distance, image height, and the magnification

7D408A9B9A7C4AE9B71D6941852464D7.description: *Demonstrate proficiency in the use of ray diagrams to find the image of an object using a converging and a diverging lens and a combination of lenses

CA0489685A024D468D34CCB79103D358.description: *Demonstrate proficiency in solving problems that use the mirror equation to calculate the focal length of a mirror, image distance, image height, and the magnification.

BB36762DB1834B35B0DAFD4D15EDD108.description: *Demonstrate proficiency in the use of ray diagrams to find the image of an object using a converging and a diverging mirror.

3E65D58C83544CA290B0276FB062E1B2.description: Apply Snell’s law to the solution of problems * including critical angle.

113ED866A1CC4AB784BFCD055CA4C56E.description: Determine the speed of light and wavelength of a light in some medium with an index of refraction of n.

775C13E90A89427AB1B9032C5E0483F6.description: Calculate the energy of a photon given the frequency or wavelength of the EM wave that it’s in.

3EA84BFA06384B49B716E76E322C3A4F.description: Use the wave equation to calculate frequency or wavelength given one of these.

B664C33852F64031970C4663F5DBF328.description: *How waves behave when they go through a slit about the size of their wavelength or hit an edge. (diffraction)

E5DCD3BFB77D4126A8587B62CBF748E3.description: *Understand how mirrors or lenses form real and virtual images

DC813163DB1C44E7A73A243CC9874292.description: *Define the following terms for spherical mirrors or lenses: principal axis, focal point, and focal length

F4812938C2504BD5A345FE4DD8D36663.description: Know that mirrors reflect and lenses refract

8A236C4A840E4753AD2F04F3C3AF667C.description: Explain the dispersion of light and the production of the visible spectrum

AC1C372067634B4CB911A36215866B83.description: *The concepts of critical angle and total internal reflection; the critical angle is measured in the higher n medium.

CBE9600FD914499982F5CE50006F003E.description: Know the angle of refraction being greater or less than the angle of incidence depending on if the n of the medium the light is entering to the n of the medium it’s coming from.

42C02262ADE7455B9B472F399CDA3F96.description: Know the effect of the medium’s index of refraction on the wavelength of the light in the medium compared to that in the air.

8475A0E0D25442F2A82523ADD761C04A.description: Know that frequency of the light is unaffected by refraction or reflection.

18296ACFAF7440CDB0D7DD0B424D2B96.description: Understand the index of refraction, n, and its relation to the speed of light in the medium of that n. That n and v are inversely proportional.

8715FFD47BDD4DCC8FEC88231F2132E2.description: The energy of a photon is directly proportional to the frequency of the EM wave, as explained by Planck’s Law.

0B1045B2BE3241D2A04445C0007848EC.description: Understand that EM waves consist of photons, the smallest packet of EM energy possible.

E74DB377FA58498CB6347A9A06AAFB52.description: The electromagnetic spectrum and the relationship between frequency, wavelength, and speed of electromagnetic waves. Know that all EM travels in a vacuum at c =  e  m/s

2E0EDF8245394A0080899C6146D8D72F.description: Know how electromagnetic waves are produced by a charged vibrating object

58E84622A49F4CC99EA6257F59976AA3.description: Understand that light behaves as an electromagnetic wave or a particle depending on the way it behaves in an experiment.

4F51730BA7584101910937396C3D32C1.description: State the nature of light and its characteristics and properties.

87468B7BE7054C1DA276192A50775646.description: Using a vertical displacement vs. time graph, identify the number of cycles and the period of the simple harmonic motion.

BE308B95F2D34B6A8C8E33978565D38E.description: Know how speed, acceleration, elastic force, kinetic energy and spring potential energy compare at the equilibrium position and the amplitudes (maximum or zero?).

3D90DC8F55C74DCFBA6D1E96BA5009B8.description: Find the wave propagation speed on a d vs. t graph.

6C9ACF95157142648374A87B883D9551.description: Apply the period equation for a pendulum and know what factors influence the period and in what way.

A2C41A6D14A94B869090D6F4D9E6213C.description: Solve for the frequency of a higher harmonic given the fundamental frequency, or solve for the fundamental given several consecutive harmonics, determining if the resonating object is a stretched string (*and open and closed end pipes).

C7CD9A49AE054F47A99C2BFDA40CCC38.description: Be able to draw standing waves for the fundamental frequency (  st harmonic) and any higher harmonics in a string (*and in open and close ended pipes) Be able to find the wavelength of any harmonic given the length of the string, *or pipe.

6CDCE60AF24F4E42B6498F585AF46C2F.description: Understand how the different variables in the wave speed equation for a stretched string relate. Know that you can only change the wave speed of a mechanical wave by changing the medium! *Use the wave speed equation to solve problems where mass per length of string, tension in spring and speed of the wave in the string are the variable.

C179A029721F43998A3A2FDE303B6EC3.description: Use the period equations for a mass-spring system to find the period or frequency of the system. Do the same with a pendulum.

F3E429C8660041049988695B5C0258DC.description: Apply the principle of conservation of mechanical energy for an object moving with SHM

1CD03F5C3D7144E2A9676F9C490F5BF2.description: Apply Hooke’s Law and Newton’s  nd law of motion to find the acceleration of an object at any point in its SHM.

001777C7C33F46F0AD65D5DA37487C1B.description: Find the spring constant from a graph of stretch (or compressional) force vs. stretch (or compression) distance, or from a picture of a spring before a mass is added and then after the mass is added. Find stretch distance or compression distance from the difference in the lengths of the spring before and after the stretch or compression.

9634C719A4C84255B82BE01756A03A7E.description: Calculate the frequency of SHM from a d vs. t graph or from a v vs. t graph of an object in SHM. (This requires finding the time for one cycle, the period, and then finding its reciprocal)

71B6157C37694C9E9E21AF61D79A6931.description: Realize that mechanical waves require a medium to wave through; sound cannot travel in a vacuum! Electromagnetic waves (light for example) can travel through a vacuum.

670B95ECFE0D451BA1237335401E08CB.description: Explain what the Doppler effect with a picture of the wave fronts from the sound source, and how it affects the wavelength and frequency and speed of the sound as heard by the observer compared to that heard by the person at the sound source.

426745C20F904C9EA0A2D1B0C33E04F7.description: Describe under what conditions a Doppler effect happens.

CDE5D500B2BE427794C3A0C7F2EA199B.description: Describe how a standing wave is produced and identify the nodes and antinode. (In strings, *open pipes, and closed pipes.)

C7DE9EDB720B4F51B89DF62C90198C05.description: Explain the interference of sound waves and the formation of beats. Determine the difference in the two waves’ frequencies from the beaty frequency.

B435C9156C90491295665F05310DF3ED.description: State and apply the principle of superposition.

1AAA8C5FC05945568880DD359B1AABBD.description: Define interference and distinguish between constructive and destructive interference.

CD8BB4BB20BD475D8D83100473FFD5BA.description: Describe the behavior of waves at a boundary: fixed-end, free-end. (Phase shift or not?)

5CBBEC6A8B7A48298A34634C756E4DDD.description: Know that waves carry energy, but that the net displacement of the medium carrying the wave is zero. But in one cycle, a medium’s particle will travel four amplitudes.

90AC3B7DC4574E1BA2CFEC53721F43A1.description: Know the two types of waves and the differences in the SHM of the particles in either—transverse and longitudinal (compressional). Know that sound is longitudinal.

0016D0B4C2344D208FB0CA1602E54454.description: Understand that that the energy carried in a wave is directly proportional to the amplitude of the wave. Recognize that the amplitude is the maximum displacement from the equilibrium position.

715F35AD578840B99B9AA3F81317FB12.description: Understand that the frequency of a sound wave is perceived as pitch, and the amplitude of the sound wave is perceived as volume.

A33106E4632145F8883F42B26635192D.description: Understand that the frequency of a wave is equal to the frequency of the vibrating source of the wave, and doesn’t change as the wave enters another medium.

6BCC54FF424E4BA48C9007B2965A3AE3.description: Understand that the velocity of a wave depends on the medium that the wave is waving through. The more elastic the medium, the more tension in the string, the warmer the medium, the faster the wave. *Find the velocity of a sound wave in air given the temperature of the air.

2E3EF823C4B8437FA534CD3F045B7E95.description: Understand the relationship between wave speed, wavelength, and frequency, and that this equation applies for all waves—mechanical or electromagnetic.

BB0141AFC11F4107A9E8F7B66E9E2BB7.description: Know that a wavelength is and how to measure it on a displacement of medium vs. distance traveled by wave graph.

BF072C5082344929BE41B716BD42E48A.description: State that the law of conservation of mechanical energy applies unless energy is lost due to friction (called damping). Damping is a gradual decreasing of the amplitude.

829E36834A8447C1AA40354FD7DCE75B.description: Define and identify the following terms on a d vs. t graph of SHM: equilibrium position, amplitude, cycle, period.

2FA05BD7BEBA4FDC8503DF229AAE138A.description: Understand that in SHM, the elastic force, the velocity, the acceleration, the spring potential energy, and the kinetic energy are constantly varying, and are related to the displacement from the equilibrium position; be able to indicate at which displacement (maximum—called the amplitude, or at the equilibrium position) each of these quantities is maximum and where each of these is zero. Also know that displacement and elastic force vectors are in opposite directions, elastic force and acceleration are in the same direction.

6775E73341314DE0800956694DF1C708.description: Understand that simple harmonic motion is an oscillation or vibration that graphs out as a sine or cosine wave when displacement from the equilibrium position or velocity of the particle is plotted vs. time.

911BF58D55C74619A01C4969557FF7D2.description: Interpret velocity vs. time graphs of two-body collinear collisions and separations.

BC8821AC8C704ABDBB51D305D0BA2E8C.description: Find linear impulse from applied force and contact time, or from mass and change in velocity of object due to the applied force

8E2A7E46E657443D91DDB7B0522B7E73.description: *Find the impulse from a F vs. t graph.

B8A18BA340664C5B9B06976B9A8D62FB.description: Interpret  -d d vs. t graphs or v vs. t graphs of collisions or separations to determine the impulse due to a collision or separation.

D09878D4D6DF4C0BB2710B6067721BB7.description: Demonstrate proficiency in solving problems involving conservation of momentum in collisions and separations in one dimension (*and in two dimensions)

872C3F606B0F419FB5ADA3BAE05195BD.description: Understand that the impulse of objects colliding or separating is the same magnitude but opposite direction for each object because the contact force is equal and opposite and the contact time is the same (Newton’s third law), and that the acceleration of the smaller object is greater (Newton’s second law).

7C384CC347E1498AA8920DBE21AA32C7.description: Understand that conservation of kinetic energy only applies to elastic collisions. That conservation of momentum applies to all collisions and separations if no outside unbalanced force is added.

3EBD058D1BDE40DC981A8231EF25CED0.description: Recognize examples of inelastic and totally inelastic and elastic collisions, and separations.

B7B42F3061D340F8BDC4384BC276DB2A.description: Understand that momentum of a system is conserved if the system is closed (no forces outside the system acts on the system [such as friction]).

D9582D8E28CD4818B0000CA48953A4AA.description: Understand that in order for an object to undergo a change in momentum (called impulse), an unbalanced and external force (net force) must be exerted on the object over a period of time.

A30FB0011E0446F2A1397594EAAEC81F.description: Understand that momentum and change in momentum (impulse) are vectors.

602C00639A0A49859DEE921C6B54A4C7.description: Understand the difference between momentum and kinetic energy.

C64E2AD7A78F4CDBAD9A5BE905E61818.description: Demonstrate proficiency in using the work energy theorem in situations that involve conservative and non-conservative forces.

CD09BF31A14E4BC48A7DCB6987808040.description: Use bar graphs to show the kinetic energy and the potential energy before and after the change.

A68D70D7B4DE498A84DC1D8D90E595DA.description: Calculate the work from the area under the curve of a force vs. displacement graph.

2E083BA283CD49AABA1336E690EECF59.description: Understand that energy associated with or caused by the motion of objects is called kinetic energy. Examples include energy of a moving object, sound, electromagnetic rays like light.

5A595AB3DB6F4CB5B32AE8CAB3C177E0.description: Understand that energy associated with the position of an object in a field is called potential energy. Examples include: gravitational, electrical, magnetic, nuclear, chemical, elastic.

A90EFEC3968B4945AACDC71C1F572972.description: Understand the first Law of Thermodynamics (the law of conservation of energy): energy cannot be created or destroyed but can be transformed to other forms.

CFA5BF1922C947C2B90FB9D66AD00862.description: State that energy is the ability to do work on another object.

320216CB7BEE406785222A1A314BE87A.description: Define and apply the concepts of work done by a constant force accounting for the angle between the displacement and the applied force.

24D7E17BA9F0404C9CB8A4111B133AD5.description: Know that mechanical energy is conserved in conservative systems (systems where there is no non-conservative force, i.e. friction) and that mechanical energy is lost in nonconservative systems due to frictional work escaping as heat. But energy is conserved even if heat is produced.

1DE8ED335B20477691A94FA46F9892AF.description: Distinguish between kinetic energy and gravitational potential energy and know that the sum of these is mechanical energy.

A218A1F261E34BDFBC768912FFFF5618.description: Understand that energy is conserved within a system.

6D47E8DAA78D449FA78D67E31076C5E0.description: Relate orbital period, orbital circumference, and orbital velocity and solve for one of these given the other two.

A1643B1C41804507A31918A09E888EA3.description: *Be able to describe Kepler’s three laws of planetary motion. Use Kepler’s third law to calculate period or orbital radius given one of them and the period and orbital of the other. (If it’s the sun being orbited, use the Earth with an orbital radius of 1 AU, and a period of 1year as one of the planets.

4FAA88719CC6484586174A3D04E4FD8E.description: Use (*derive) the acceleration due to gravity at the surface of a planet of radius r based on the weight equation and the universal law of gravity equation. Repeat for any distance above the surface of that planet. Know that the acceleration due to gravity is the centripetal acceleration for an orbiting object.

AEC86AFC3C4F419CAB21D408641F2EE9.description: Demonstrate proficiency in solving problems (* involving banked curves, conical pendulum), motion in horizontal circles, motion in vertical circles at topmost and lowest most points.

D0613368ACDC4B10BA74D8D4097B68F3.description: Use (*derive) the centripetal force equation based on Newton’s second law of motion.

CA5B7FF6C2FE435FAA7A95EFA4AFD3F1.description: Use (*derive) the equation for centripetal acceleration of an object moving at constant tangential speed in a circle of radius r.

42A2BD7B0EFA482B90FD33E3635B1673.description: Identify the centripetal force in any given problem as friction, [*the x component of the object’s normal force on banked turns or of tension in conical pendulums], electrostatic force, or gravitational force.

DE573E4023D14B7C997DC7D0CB78015B.description: Understand that “weightlessness” in orbit or free fall is “normal forcelessness”; weight is still present and is providing the centripetal force that keeps the object falling in orbit (or falling downward).

A3C1D9E62C1C4743A60CA9933BD73DCB.description: Explain and apply the relationship between the tangential speed and the orbital radius of a satellite.

7446B8983654481196F7381AC3BAE4C9.description: Visualize the gravitational field around a mass as the path a smaller mass would fall when released. Realize that as the distance from the planet increases, these field lines are less crowded together, thus the field decreases.and is defined as weight divided by mass. Realize that mass is a constant for a given object regardless of the gravitational pull on it (its weight). Realize that if the mass is big enough, the field lines are essentially parallel to each other at the surface of the planet. That the strength of the gravitation field is g,

BABC448E198F412F8D85DC3C67A7BE0F.description: State and apply Newton’s Law of universal gravitation. Describe the effect on gravity when the distance between the two objects is changed and/or the mass of either or both of the objects is changed. Understand that the gravitational pull is equal between the two objects, but in opposite directions as explained in Newton’s third law of motion.

E24FC7A1D9E3433B8E41ED181B9A3774.description: State the relationship between mass and centripetal acceleration (and thus mass and velocity) in the centripetal force equation.

CB24AD63FDFE4E888CB8C12A562074E5.description: Understand the relationship between radius and centripetal acceleration as shown in the ac equation.

F7CB3C1D8DF249CC82F7BC67BD2E230E.description: Understand the characteristics of uniform circular motion: constant tangential speed, changing orbital velocity because direction is changing, zero tangential acceleration, constant centripetal acceleration.

1401080FFDB040C4ACD4AD2ED8353734.description: That because centripetal force is a net force, it causes a net acceleration in the same direction (centripetal acceleration), and this acceleration changes the direction but not the magnitude of the tangential velocity.

36E60464BD3249EF9D52EE7BFE823D0D.description: Understand that a net external force must be directed toward the center of a circular path to keep an object traveling in a circular path, called the centripetal force. Release this force and be able to predict the motion of the object according to the first law of motion.

55FAA6FD27C048998163ABA798A841D9.description: Use Newton’s Laws of Motion with a FBD to solve either equilibrium problems (with or without friction or coefficient of friction) or acceleration problems for a two body connected system (vertically, horizontally, *and on ramps.

E79ECDC28FE64F35A9AC91129D30385D.description: Use Newton’s Laws of Motion with a FBD to solve either equilibrium or constant acceleration problems (with or without friction or coefficient of friction) on level surfaces *and on ramps.

A85BA58E636540A08887D43AC478E069.description: Use Newton’s Laws of Motion with a FBD to solve constant acceleration problems (horizontal or vertical) with or without friction (using coefficients of friction)

AD3D680369284381BF006BB8D237C9ED.description: Use Newton’s Laws of Motion with a FBD to solve equilibrium problems (horizontal or vertical) with or without friction (using coefficients of friction)

919253BC45ED4D78BD35400E51DC9077.description: Accurately draw or interpret free body diagrams (FBD) for objects in equilibrium and objects experiencing linear acceleration either vertically or horizontally or with objects connected by a string. [*and for objects on ramps].

449B0FBFAC2E4E0C84044F4BF9B0D048.description: State what an equilibrant is and how to calculate it given other forces

A7AC645B233741BB9375266ED4FDB1A0.description: State the conditions for translational equilibrium and the two ways an object could be in translational equilibrium

69A334DA878D4E21B83C3A6FBC18D87E.description: State and apply Newton’s third law of motion.

4CDCE9B5C60C4A7A866F07B368B89BD3.description: Understand that the direction of the net force on an object is always the same direction as the acceleration it causes.

EB0261567B3A4D64979BC33EFDFC97C5.description: State and apply Newton’s second law of motion, and to understand the relationship between the other two terms if one of the terms in the equation stays constant.

459F13DFD90D4AC2B0F914734F97D204.description: State and apply Newton’s first law of motion to everyday events.

05DAFD8344E4432A93618D5C34A375BB.description: Differentiate between static and kinetic friction.

B34DDF9A4DF9488992F157B180EC9B99.description: Determine the direction and cause of normal force.

0615BACA311F4BA79BADB9610A8DABBA.description: Distinguish between mass and weight, and how to calculate the weight using g.

83BF049CD17D404990E14E9812CF1A95.description: Distinguish between contact forces and field forces, identifying the agent that causes the force.

C9D07279A7EE484FAD7A2EB883AB5A55.description: Use the kinematics equations to solve  d projectile problems: horizontal launched and angle launched--rainbow trajectory [*and partial rainbow trajectory]

B4B6512F57074352BAE0A9BDE99F052D.description: Find the direction and magnitude of a vector from its components.

B15DB1B7B620403388D6D72D740A06F9.description: Resolve a vector into its horizontal (x) and vertical (y) components, graphically and analytically.

45D58F3914EB4A6F81D4A6A05A98EB0A.description: Determine the vector sum or vector difference of two vectors by a graphical method and an analytic method. (vectors collinear or perpendicular to each other; just use a graphical method if the vectors are not collinear or perpendicular, or if there are more than three vectors that aren’t collinear and or perpendicular.)

8CC67B0010804C04B64A187169709DB6.description: Analyze motion graphs by finding the slope of a tangent on a d vs. t (and knowing that it’s velocity) and on a v vs. t graph (knowing that it’s acceleration), and on either graph: where the velocity is negative, zero, or positive, where the velocity is zero, increasing, decreasing, or staying constant, where the object is experiencing acceleration and whether that acceleration is negative or positive, *finding the displacement on a v vs. t graph by the area under the curve.

AD2B1952AF664AE3BF204D41F57A912E.description: Compare and contrast uniform motion, constant accelerated motion, and  d projectile motion.

5F5DC03EA0A64CEF988D80F55CF0FFC7.description: Use the four kinematics equations to solve  d kinematics problems, including free fall problems and two stage problems where the acceleration changes.

F3A31DF3D8CD428C8074537576733490.description: Express the motion of an object using narrative, mathematical, and graphical representations.

513EA9B7A1024A6C889598FFE3FA8826.description: Show the relationship between launch angle and range of a projectile with a given launch velocity.

A201CEBF0A5B4929B71A73DD77C999C6.description: Understand that the vertical and horizontal motion of a projectile are independent of each other, comparing the accelerations of the two.

647173410F3F4CA1981C919BD3275C79.description: Understand that displacement is change in position, velocity is rate of change of position with time, acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with time, and change is expressed by subtracting initial values from final values.

260CD029E658479A86890787963393AA.description: Understand that displacement, velocity, and acceleration are vector quantities and therefore require magnitude and direction.

03A4A5559291479A8B821C60B5961136.description: Be able to solve for an unknown in an equation using algebra.

04281C39FEE6427285B7F0ACEF093EA2.description: Use the calculator to do scientific notation problems.

411615E66E384BA6BDE97B1F19A6A9D1.description: Take an equation and determine which symbols are directly proportional to each other and which are inversely proportional to each other. Determine what happens to the variable on the left side of the equation when one of the variables on the right side is doubled, etc.

1C4B55BD060A4161A7BBE410F22F73E9.description: Construct a graph from collected data with or without a graphing program, find and interpret the slope of a graph, determine the independent and dependent variables on the graph, determine the x-value from the y-value or vice versa, extrapolate, determine the relationship between the x and y values from the shape and direction of the graph, find the area under the graph line and its significance, determine the significance of the x- or y-intercept.

4D9C0D0C06D8422BB36DB28D682AB27E.description: Use trigonometric functions to find any side of a right angle triangle given two of the other sides, and find the angle within a right angle triangle given two sides of the triangle.
